newsitem.title: USA: SEC probing former NASD muni examiner's charges.
newsitem.headline: SEC probing former NASD muni examiner's charges.

text.p: SEC is reviewing charges by former National Association of Securities Dealers examiner Theresa Carr that NASD avoided aggressively probing abuses in the municipal bond market, Carr's lawyer said Wednesday.
Jacob Zamansky, a partner with Singer Zamansky in New York City, said he and Carr met with officials of SEC's office of compliance, inspections and examinations on Friday, at their request.
Lori Richards, director of SEC's office of compliance, inspections and examinations, was unavailable for comment.
"They met with us for about three hours. They were taking copious notes," Zamansky said about the meeting. "They basically wanted to hear the backup to her charges."
Carr was a senior compliance examiner in the region 10 office until June 19, when, according to a complaint she filed in New York Supreme Court last month, she was effectively forced to resign.

Carr, who is seeking $20 million in penalties from NASD, said she was pushed out after uncovering and pursuing violations by major securities firms of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board's "pay-to-play" rule G-37.
The rule restricts political contributions by bond firms to state and local elected officials with whom they do business.
The SEC oversees the enforcement activities of NASD.
